conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D, and the task is to predict which container (E or F) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
The image shows four inlets labeled A, B, C, and D at the top, various colored ramps (orange, black, red, yellow, purple, pink), and two containers labeled E (blue) and F (yellow) at the bottom.
Inlet A is positioned at the far-left and is connected to a long orange bar ramp.
Liquid from A meets the long orange bar ramp, which sends it down-and-right.
Liquid from A next meets the long black bar ramp, which tips the stream straight down just inside the blue mouth.
Liquid from A flows into container E.
Inlet B is positioned slightly to the right of A and is connected to the same long orange bar ramp.
Liquid from B meets the long orange bar ramp, which sends it down-and-right.
Liquid from B arrives still high enough to hit the red bar ramp.
The red bar deflects the stream leftward so that it drops into the blue mouth.
Liquid from B flows into container E.
Inlet C is positioned centrally and directly hits the red bar ramp.
Liquid from C slides a good way rightward along the red bar ramp.
Liquid from C falls past the blue mouth and strikes the little yellow funnel bar.
The yellow funnel guides the liquid into the yellow well.
Liquid from C flows into container F.
Inlet D is positioned at the far-right and is connected to a thin purple bar ramp.
Liquid from D meets the thin purple bar ramp, which sends it down-and-left.
Liquid from D falls to the pink bar ramp and then to the same yellow funnel bar.
The yellow funnel guides the liquid into the yellow well.
Liquid from D flows into container F.
Final result: A and B empty into container E, while C and D empty into container F.
